seo.title: About
seo.description: Learn about Geetanjali - ancient wisdom from the Bhagavad Geeta for modern ethical decisions. Open source, private, and free.

hero.title: About Geetanjali
hero.subtitle: Ancient wisdom for life's difficult decisions

quote.text: You have the right to work, but never to the fruit of work. You should never engage in action for the sake of reward, nor should you long for inaction.

story: Life presents moments when the right choice isn't obvious—when duty conflicts with desire, when multiple paths seem equally valid, or when the consequences of any decision feel uncertain.

For over two thousand years, people have turned to the Bhagavad Geeta in such moments. Not for simple answers, but for perspectives that illuminate the question itself. The Geeta is a 700-verse conversation about how to act when the way forward isn't clear, how to balance personal values with responsibility, and how to find equanimity amid life's complexity.

Geetanjali brings this wisdom into a form you can engage with directly—whether you're facing a career crossroads, navigating relationships, working through ethical questions, or simply seeking clarity. Share a dilemma, and receive thoughtful perspectives grounded in verses from the Geeta, presented accessibly and without sectarian framing.
This is not meant to replace your judgment or offer definitive answers. Think of Geetanjali as one thoughtful companion among many—a way to encounter timeless philosophy when you need it most.

items.title: Why the Bhagavad Geeta?
items.description: The Geeta addresses universal questions that transcend time and culture: How do we act rightly when outcomes are uncertain? How do we honor our responsibilities while staying true to ourselves? Its teachings have guided seekers across traditions—practical philosophy that meets you where you are.

items.title: Accessible, Not Prescriptive
items.description: Geetanjali presents the Geeta's teachings accessibly, focusing on practical Vedantic principles—self-knowledge, ethical action, and finding meaning amid complexity. The goal is to offer perspectives that help you think more clearly, not to tell you what to do.

items.title: Honoring the Source
items.description: Geetanjali includes all 701 verses of the Bhagavad Geeta plus the 9 verses of Geeta Dhyanam, with Sanskrit text, transliteration, and translations. Audio recitations preserve the sound of the original. The text is treated with the respect it deserves—presented faithfully, not reduced to soundbites.

items.title: Open Source
items.description: The entire codebase is publicly available. Transparency builds trust, and contributions are welcome.

items.title: Private
items.description: Your dilemmas and reflections belong to you. Geetanjali doesn't track, profile, or share your data.

items.title: Open & Free
items.description: Access to wisdom shouldn't have a price. All features are available to everyone, always.
